skos.definition: A progressive neurodegenerative disease and the most common cause of dementia, characterized pathologically by extracellular amyloid-beta plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
skos.scopeNote: Most common cause of dementia; 60-80% of all dementia cases; major public health burden

content.title: Alzheimer Disease
content.summary: Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, characterized by insidious onset of memory impairment (especially episodic memory) followed by progressive decline in other cognitive domains. Pathologically defined by amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, it has limited but meaningful symptomatic treatments and is a focus of intensive disease-modifying therapy research.
key_points: Most common cause of dementia (60-80% of cases)
Hallmark: early episodic memory loss with preserved remote memory initially
Pathology: amyloid-beta plaques (extracellular) and tau tangles (intracellular)
APOE ε4 allele is strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD
Diagnosis primarily clinical; biomarkers (CSF, PET) increasingly used
Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) for mild-moderate disease
New anti-amyloid therapies (aducanumab, lecanemab) for early disease
content.statement: Alzheimer disease represents a major public health challenge as populations age worldwide. Understanding its clinical presentation, pathophysiology, and management is essential for all clinicians, as early recognition allows for symptomatic treatment, advance care planning, and potential enrollment in disease-modifying therapy trials.

explanation.intuition: Think of Alzheimer disease as a 'filing cabinet' problem in the brain. The hippocampus, which files new memories, is affected early, so patients can't form new memories (anterograde amnesia) even though old memories filed long ago remain accessible. As the disease spreads, other brain functions fail progressively.
explanation.key_insight: The amyloid cascade hypothesis suggests that accumulation of amyloid-beta initiates a cascade leading to tau pathology, neuroinflammation, synaptic dysfunction, and neuronal death. While amyloid-targeting therapies have shown plaque clearance, clinical benefit remains modest, suggesting the pathophysiology is more complex than initially thought.
explanation.technical_details: Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is cleaved by β-secretase and γ-secretase to produce amyloid-beta (Aβ) peptides. Aβ42 is particularly prone to aggregation into oligomers and fibrils. Tau is a microtubule-associated protein; hyperphosphorylation causes it to aggregate into neurofibrillary tangles. The spreading pattern of tau pathology (Braak staging) correlates better with clinical symptoms than amyloid burden.

definitions_glossary.amyloid_beta: Peptide (36-43 amino acids) that aggregates into plaques; Aβ42 is the most pathogenic form
definitions_glossary.neurofibrillary_tangles: Intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein; correlate with cognitive decline
definitions_glossary.tau_protein: Microtubule-associated protein that stabilizes neuronal cytoskeleton; hyperphosphorylation leads to tangles
definitions_glossary.APOE_epsilon4: Apolipoprotein E allele; strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD; affects amyloid clearance
definitions_glossary.episodic_memory: Memory for personal experiences and specific events; affected early in AD (hippocampus)
definitions_glossary.hippocampus: Medial temporal lobe structure critical for memory formation; shows early atrophy in AD
definitions_glossary.cholinesterase_inhibitors: Drugs (donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) that increase acetylcholine; symptomatic treatment
definitions_glossary.memantine: NMDA receptor antagonist; reduces glutamate excitotoxicity; for moderate-severe AD
definitions_glossary.amyloid_PET: Imaging using Florbetapir or Florbetaben to detect brain amyloid plaques
definitions_glossary.CSF_biomarkers: Low Aβ42, elevated total tau and phospho-tau in AD; support diagnosis
definitions_glossary.Braak_staging: System classifying tau pathology spread from entorhinal cortex to neocortex
definitions_glossary.mild_cognitive_impairment: MCI - cognitive decline beyond normal aging but not meeting dementia criteria; high risk for AD
definitions_glossary.sundowning: Worsening confusion and agitation in late afternoon/evening; common in moderate-severe AD
definitions_glossary.lecanemab: Anti-amyloid monoclonal antibody; FDA-approved for early AD; modest clinical benefit

pathophysiology.mechanism: Progressive neurodegeneration driven by amyloid-beta accumulation and tau pathology, leading to synaptic dysfunction, neuroinflammation, and neuronal loss, particularly in hippocampus, entorhinal cortex, and association cortices.

late_onset_sporadic: APOE ε4 - strongest risk factor; 2-3× risk (heterozygous), 8-12× (homozygous)
Other genes: TREM2, CLU, CR1, PICALM (small effect sizes)

stages.preclinical: Biomarker evidence of AD pathology without symptoms (10-20 years before clinical onset)
stages.MCI_due_to_AD: Noticeable memory decline without functional impairment
stages.mild_AD: Memory loss affecting daily activities; word-finding difficulty; getting lost
stages.moderate_AD: Requires assistance with ADLs; behavioral changes; sundowning
stages.severe_AD: Total dependence; minimal communication; incontinence; immobility

cognitive_symptoms: Episodic memory impairment (earliest and most prominent)

clinical_diagnosis: Insidious onset and progressive cognitive decline
Exclusion of other causes (vascular, metabolic, psychiatric)

biomarkers.A_amyloid: Low CSF Aβ42 or positive amyloid PET
biomarkers.T_tau: Elevated CSF phospho-tau or positive tau PET
biomarkers.N_neurodegeneration: Elevated CSF total tau, hippocampal atrophy on MRI, hypometabolism on FDG-PET

workup: MRI brain (exclude other pathology, assess atrophy)
Labs: TSH, B12, metabolic panel, RPR
Consider: CSF biomarkers, amyloid PET, genetic testing (if early-onset)

cholinesterase_inhibitors.benefit: Modest improvement in cognition and function; slows decline

anti_amyloid_antibodies.indication: Early AD with confirmed amyloid pathology
anti_amyloid_antibodies.efficacy: Modest slowing of cognitive decline (27% reduction with lecanemab)
anti_amyloid_antibodies.monitoring: MRI at baseline and during treatment

behavioral_management: Low-dose antipsychotics for severe agitation/psychosis (use cautiously - black box warning)

prognosis.variability: Wide range (3-20 years); depends on age at onset and comorbidities
prognosis.cause_of_death: Usually aspiration pneumonia, other infections, or failure to thrive

learning_objectives: Describe the clinical features distinguishing Alzheimer disease from other dementias
Explain the amyloid cascade hypothesis and tau pathology
Identify major genetic risk factors for early-onset and late-onset AD
Outline the diagnostic workup including biomarkers and imaging
Compare and contrast symptomatic treatments (cholinesterase inhibitors, memantine)
Discuss new disease-modifying therapies and their limitations
clinical_pearls: Early episodic memory loss with preserved remote memory = think AD
MMSE and MoCA miss early disease - use detailed neuropsychological testing if suspicious
Don't diagnose AD without MRI - always rule out vascular, tumor, NPH
APOE testing is not recommended for asymptomatic individuals (no prevention proven)
Anti-amyloid therapies require confirmed amyloid pathology (PET or CSF) and monitoring for ARIA
Behavioral symptoms often respond better to non-pharmacologic interventions than medications

common_question_stems: Elderly patient with progressive memory loss and word-finding difficulty
Choosing between donepezil and memantine based on disease stage
exam_tips: AD = early episodic memory loss; FTD = early personality/language changes
Amyloid plaques (extracellular) + tau tangles (intracellular) = AD pathology
Cholinesterase inhibitors for mild-moderate; add memantine for moderate-severe

teaching_cases.scenario: 74-year-old woman brought by family for 2 years of worsening memory. She repeats questions, gets lost driving, and missed paying bills. Remote memory intact.
teaching_cases.key_findings: MMSE 22/30, MRI shows bilateral hippocampal atrophy, CSF shows low Aβ42 and elevated phospho-tau
teaching_cases.management: Start donepezil, caregiver education, safety assessment (driving), advance care planning
